questions.question: Question 1: In an average young adult male, what percentage of the bodyweight is water?
questions.explanation:
In the human body, water constitutes the highest proportion of body weight. The total body water 
accounts for ~60% of body weight. Human Body Composition Compo

questions.question: Question 2: If the total body water is 60% of the body weight, what are the proportions of ECF and ICF?
questions.explanation:
When expressed as the percentage of body weight, 40% of body weight is in ICF (2/3rd of 60%), 
and 20% of body weight is in ECF (1/3rd of 60%). The 60-40-20 rule is: 60% of body weight is water, 40% is ICF, and 20% is ECF.

questions.question:
Question 3: A 60 kg adult male has a haematocrit reading of 40% and a plasma volume of 3L. What is his 
total blood volume in L?
questions.explanation:
His total blood volume is 5 litres. Calculation: 78 
Sold by @itachibot Hematocrit is a percentage, as it is 40% which equals 40/100= 0.4. (Normally, Total blood volume is 8% of body weight).

questions.question: Question 4: What is the volume of blood in ml, in a child per kg body weight?
questions.explanation:
The total blood volume of a child is around 75–80 ml/kg. In the neonatal period, it is 85 ml/kg. It rises to a peak of 105 ml/kg by the end of the first month 
and then drops progressively over ensuing months.

questions.question: Question 5: What is the water content of lean body mass is (in mL/100g of tissue)?
questions.explanation:
The water content of lean body tissue is constant at 71–72 mL/100 g of tissue. Lean body mass = Body mass - ( Adipose tissue fat mass + Bone Mass + Non-Adipose Tissue Fat 
Mass)

questions.question: Question 6: How do we measure the volume of distribution of body fluid compartments?
questions.explanation:
The volume of a fluid compartment in the body can be measured by "indicator (dye)-dilution" 
method. This method is based on the conservation of mass principle, which means that the total 
mass of a substance after dispersion in the fluid compartment will be the same as the total mass 
injected into the compartment. 79 
Sold by @itachibot Figure shows If none of the substance leaks out of the compartment, the total mass of substance in the 
compartment (Volume B × Concentration B) will equal the total mass of the substance injected 
(Volume A × Concentration A). By simple rearrangement of the equation, one can calculate the 
unknown volume of chamber B as

questions.question:
Question 7: 500 mg of mannitol was injected out of which 10% is excreted. After equilibrium, plasma 
concentration is 3.2 mg/100 ml. Calculate ECF Volume (L).
questions.explanation:
The volume of distribution can be calculated using the formula: 80 
Sold by @itachibot • V = volume of compartment • Amount injected = 500 mg • Amount of indicator excreted = 10% of 500 mg = 50mg • Plasma concentration of the indicator = 3.2 mg/100mL Calculation: 2nd method : Mannitol is a substance which leaves blood vessel but can't enter the cell. Therefore, after 
attaining equilibrium, conc. of mannitol is same in plasma and interstitial fluid Therefore, by applying dye-dilution technique, mannitol can be used to measure the volume of 
ECF (x) 81 
Sold by @itachibot Since, 10% is excreted and 10% of 500mg is 50 mg, the amount of mannitol diluted in ECF is 450 
mg (500 - 50) i.e, 450 mg is present in x From the given values, 3.2 mg is present in 100 ml, which can be re-written as 3.2/100 = 450/x Therefore x = 450 * 100 / 3.2 mL = 14,062.5 mL = 14 L Clinical : IV Mannitol is used to treat cerebral oedema (since, it doesn't cross cell membrane, it extracts 
fluid from brain cells), whereas it is contra-indicated in pulmonary edema (here the fluid 
collection is in the interstitial space)

questions.question:
Question 8: 10 g of inulin is injected IV and after equilibrium the concentration of inulin in plasma is 
50mg/100ml. If 10% of the inulin is excreted, what is the ECF volume?
questions.explanation:
Inulin is the indicator used to measure the ECF volume. (Since, inulin can cross blood vessel but 
not cell wall) Calculation: • Since 10% is excreted, volume of inulin excreted is 1 gm. The amount of inulin diluted in ECF is 
9 g ( 10 - 1) i.e, 9000mg is present in x From the given values, 50 mg is present in 100ml, which can be re-written as 50/100 = 9000/x x = 9000 * 100 / 50 = 9000 * 2 = 18,000mL = 18L Second method : • Since 10% is excreted, volume of inulin excreted is 1 gm. • Amount injected = 10g • Amount excreted = 1g Now, the concentration of inulin after equilibrium is 50 mg/100ml which is equal to 0.05 g/100ml. 
(Convert the values into same units). 82 
Sold by @itachibot Therefore, ECF volume = (10-1)*100/0.05 =18000ml = 18 L

questions.question: Question 9: Of the following compartment and indicator combinations which is true?

options.d: Total body water-Cannot be measured directly.

questions.explanation:
The ECF volume can be estimated using any of several substances that disperse in the plasma and 
interstitial fluid but do not readily permeate the cell membrane. Example- radioactive sodium, thiosulfate ion, and inulin. Hint : Sodium (Na+) can cross blood vessel but not cell wall passively (therefore used to measure 
ECF volume )

questions.question:
Question 10: A dye • which measures the plasma volume is replaced by dye Y which can diffuse out of the 
capillaries. Which of the following is true regarding the newly measured plasma volume?
questions.explanation:
As the dye diffuses out of the capillaries, the measured concentration of the dye after equilibrium 
will be less. So, as per the formula, the volume measured will be falsely high. V = (Amount Injected - Amount Excreted) / Plasma concentration of dye Detailed explanation: • Dye x measures plasma volume:- dye x doesn't have the property of crossing blood vessel. If the 
dye x have been used properly, for a normal person then the value would come around 3 L • Dye y crosses capillaries, which means it can cross any blood vessel. This property is used to 
measure the value of ECF. If the dye y is given, for a normal person then the value would come 
around 14L • Thus if dye y is given in place of x, then the value would be 14 instead of 3 which is a false and 
the obtained value is high when compared to normal value • Therefore the answer is falsely high. 83 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 11: Interstitial fluid volume is best measured using a combination of which two dyes?
questions.explanation:
Interstitial fluid volume is best measured using a combination of inulin and Evans blue. Insterstitial fluid is measured indirectly. ECF minus plasma volume gives the interstitial fluid 
value. • Best measure of ECF - Inulin • Best measure of Plasma Volume - Evans Blue (T1824)

questions.question: Question 12: Which of the following is higher in the ECF compared to ICF?
questions.explanation:
The pH of ECF is 7.4 while the pH of ICF is 7.0. There is continuous generation of H+ ions in the 
ICF due to the various metabolic processes. So, the pH of ICF is a little lower compared to ECF.

questions.question: Question 13: Which of the following is the most abundant intracellular anion?
questions.explanation:
Phosphate is the most abundant intracellular anion. • ICF • Major anion- Phosphate • Major cation- K+ • ECF • Major anion- Cl- • Cation- Na+ • Protein content in ICF is ~8 times greater than plasma (ECF) 84 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 14: How many grams of NaCl make 1 mole of NaCl?
questions.explanation:
1 mol of NaCl is 58.5 g • A mole is the gram-molecular weight of a substance (molecular weight of a substance in grams) • In this case, the molecular weight of Na-23 and Cl-35.5. • 1 mol of NaCl = 23 g + 35.5 g = 58.5 g Note • Each mole consists of 6 • 10 23 molecules. • The molecular weight of a substance is the ratio of the mass of 1/12th the mass of an atom of 
carbon-12. Because molecular weight is a ratio, it is dimensionless. • The Dalton (Da) is a unit of mass equal to the mass of 1/12th the mass of an atom of carbon-12. 
Thus molecular mass is expressed in units.

questions.question: Question 15: How much is one equivalent of calcium (molecular weight = 40)?
questions.explanation:
1 equivalent of calcium is 20 g. One equivalent is 1 mol of an ionized substance divided by its valency. For calcium in solution, 1 mol is going to be 40g and its valency is 2. Therefore, 1 equivalent of 
calcium is 40/2 = 20g.

questions.question: Question 16: The unit expressing the concentration of osmotically active particles is
questions.explanation:
85 
Sold by @itachibot The concentration of osmotically active particles is usually expressed in osmoles. Normal plasma 
osmolality is 280 to 290 mosmole/kg H2O • Example • NaCl dissociate into 2 particles- Na+ and Cl- in an ideal solution. Hence we can say that for every 
1 mole of NaCl, there are 2 osmoles. • If a solute is a non-ionizing compound such as glucose, the osmotic pressure is a function of the 
number of glucose molecules present. • NOTE: The body fluids are not ideal solutions, and although the dissociation of strong 
electrolytes is complete, the number of particles free to exert an osmotic effect is reduced owing to 
the interaction between the ions. Thus, 1mol of NaCl per litre body fluids contribute somewhat 
less than 2 osmoles. The more concentrated the solution, the greater the deviation from the ideal 
solution.

questions.question:
Question 17: A female patient was infused with a solution which leads to rapid lysis of the RBCs. Which 
solution was most likely infused?
questions.explanation:
Urea is a highly permeable solute, 300mMol/L urea solution behaves as a hypotonic solution. Urea diffuses to the inside of RBC's via UTB channels very rapidly, while the rest of the solutes in 
the ECF cannot enter the cell. So the ECF now becomes hypotonic. So, fluid enters the RBC and 
causes their lysis. Other Options : • Option A : The solution is iso-osmotic. (150mmol of NaCl contains 150mmol of Na+ and 
150mmol of Cl- ions making the total osmolality 300 mOsm/L.This is equivalent to 0.9% NaCl 
which is isotonic.) • Option B and C: The solutions are hyper-osmotic. This will lead to shrinking of the RBCs. Note : • If a cell is placed into a hypotonic solution that has a lower concentration of impermeant solutes 
(<282 mOsm/L), water will diffuse into the cell, causing it to swell. • If a cell is placed in a hypertonic solution having a higher concentration of impermeant solutes, 
water will flow out of the cell leading to cell shrinkage. 86 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 18: Normal osmolarity of plasma is mainly due to  
.
questions.explanation:
Normal plasma osmolarity (~290 mOsm/L) is mainly due to Na+ and its accompanying anions, 
principally Cl- and HCO3- • Osmolarity (mOsm/L) = 2 [Na+] (mEq/L) + 0.055 [Glucose] (mg/dL) + 0.36 [BUN] (mg/dL) • Because sodium and its associated anions (Cl- , HCO3- ) account for about 94 per cent of the 
solute in the extracellular compartment, plasma osmolarity (Posm) can be roughly approximated 
as • Posm = 2.1 x Plasma sodium concentration • With a plasma sodium concentration of 142 mEq/L, the plasma osmolarity would be estimated 
from the formula above to be about 298 mOsm/L. • In conditions associated with renal disease, the contribution of two other solutes, glucose and 
urea, should be included. • Because urea easily permeates most cell membranes, it exerts little effective osmotic pressure 
under steady-state conditions. (Ineffective osmoles) • Contribution to plasma osmolarity: • Na+ and associated anions: 270 mOsm/L • Glucose : 5 mOsm/L • Urea: 5 mOsm/L • Plasma proteins: 2 mOsm/L • Other ions: 8 mOsm/L 87 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 19: Plasma proteins contribute only slightly to the total number of osmotically active particles 
because

options.a: High molar concentration, high molecular weight
options.b: Low molar concentration, low molecular weight
options.c: Low molar concentration, high molecular weight
options.d: High molar concentration, low molecular weight

questions.explanation:
Proteins actually contribute only slightly to the total number of osmotically active particles (1 
mOsm) because of their low molar concentration and high molecular weight. Protein concentration measured as g/L may be high. However, as their molecular weight is high, 
the protein concentration in terms of moles per liter ( molar concentration) will be low. Thus, they 
contribute only slightly to the total number of osmotically active particles. Detailed explanation: Terms like high, low are always used for comparison. Here we compare 
plasma proteins and sodium (sodium is chosen because it contributes the maximum part of 
osmolarity). Look at the values given below (just for understanding ) Plasma proteins (Albumi 
n) Sodiu 
m Molar concentration 
0.75mosm/L(Low) 
270mo 
sm/L Molecular weight( 1 mole = ) 
67,000 g(High) 
23g

questions.question: Question 20: Daily water loss in sweat during normal activities is (ml)
questions.explanation:
The amount of water lost by sweating is highly variable, depending on physical activity and 
environmental temperature. The volume of sweat normally is about 100 ml/day, but in very hot 
weather or during heavy exercise fluid loss in sweat occasionally increase to 1 to 2 L/hour.

questions.question: Question 21: Which type of disturbance of body fluids is observed in sweating?
questions.explanation:
Sweating loss of water Hyperosmotic volume contraction • The osmolarity of ECF increases because sweat is hyposmotic (relatively more water than salt is 
lost). • ECF volume decreases because of the loss of volume in the sweat. • Water shifts out of ICF; as a result of the shift, ICF osmolarity increases until it is equal to ECF 
osmolarity, and ICF volume decreases. • Plasma protein concentration increases because of the decrease in ECF volume. Although 
hematocrit might also be expected to increase, it remains unchanged because of the water shifts 
out of the RBCs, decreasing their volume and offsetting the concentrating effect of the decreased 
ECF volume. • So,Loss of hypotonic fluid causes hypertonic volume contraction.

questions.question:
Question 22: A 73-year-old diabetic man is brought to the emergency with an altered sensorium. He is 
dehydrated and his blood glucose is 550mg/dl. A hyperosmolar, hyperglycemic state is 
suspected. Which of the given formulae can correctly evaluate his serum osmolality?
questions.explanation:
88 
Sold by @itachibot Calculated serum osmolality = 2 sodium + (glucose/18) + (BUN/2.8). In the given clinical scenario, the patient with untreated type 2 diabetes mellitus has most likely 
developed a hyperosmolar, hyperglycemic state. His serum osmolality will be significantly raised. The principal determinants of osmolality of serum are the concentrations of sodium, glucose and 
urea (blood urea nitrogen or BUN). Osmolality is defined as a measure of the osmoles (Osm) of solute per kilogram of solvent 
(osmol/kg or Osm/kg). The osmolality of the intracellular and extracellular fluids is maintained 
between 290 and 310 mOsm in each compartment.

questions.question:
Question 23: Addition of 500 mL of hypertonic saline to the extracellular fluid leads to 73 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The images shown in the figure are called Darrow Yannet Diagrams. They depict the change in 
plasma osmolality and plasma volume in various conditions. If a hypertonic solution is added to the extracellular fluid, the extracellular osmolarity increases 
and causes osmosis of water out of the cells into the extracellular compartment • ECF osmolality increases. ECF volume increases. • As, ECF osmolality rises, fluid from ICF moves to ECF till osmotic equilibrium is established. So, • ICF osmolality rises. ICF volume decreases. Therefore, the net effect is an increase in extracellular volume (greater than the volume of fluid 
added), a decrease in intracellular volume, and a rise in osmolarity in both compartments. Note : The dotted line in the diagram is the change after either addition or removal of fluid

questions.question:
Question 24: The following Darrow Yannet diagram is suggestive of which condition? ( dotted line denotes 
the change caused by the condition)
questions.explanation:
89 
Sold by @itachibot In the given darrow yannet diagram, there is hypoosmostic volume expansion which is suggestive 
of SIADH. • In SIADH there is excessive secretion of ADH. So, excess water is retained in the body. • So, ECF volume rises. ECF osmolality decreases. • ECF fluid enters ICF untill osmotic equilibrium is re-established. • So, ICF volume rises. ICF osmolality decreases. The Darrow Yannet diagrams of various conditions are shown above

questions.question:
Question 25: The following Darrow Yannet diagram is suggestive of which condition? Note : The solid line 
is the original fluid compartment and the colour shaded compartment within the dotted line 
denotes the change caused by the condition.
questions.explanation:
90 
Sold by @itachibot In adrenal insufficiency there is hypo-osmotic volume contraction. Aldosterone deficiency leads to 
increased sodium loss (loss of hyperosmotic fluid). • The osmolarity of ECF decreases. • ECF volume decreases because of the loss of volume. • Water shifts into ICF; as a result of the shift, ICF osmolarity decreases until it is equal to ECF 
osmolarity, and ICF volume increases. • So, loss of hypertonic fluid causes hypotonic volume contraction. Please note that in the diagram, the horizontal axis represents volume and vertical axis represents 
osmolarity. The Darrow Yannet diagrams of various conditions are shown above. 91 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 26: Various safety factors prevent excessive fluid accumulation in the interstitial spaces. Total 
safety factor against edema is (mmHg)
questions.explanation:
The total safety factor against edema is about 17 mmHg. Summary of safety factors that prevent edema is: • The safety factor caused by low tissue compliance in the negative pressure range is about 3 mm 
Hg • The safety factor caused by increased lymph flow is about 7 mm Hg • The safety factor caused by washdown of proteins from the interstitial spaces is about 7 mm Hg Therefore, the total safety factor against edema is about 17 mm Hg.

questions.question:
Question 27: You are an intern and want to determine the quantity of IV fluids needed for a patient. How 
much amount of transient loss/insensible loss per day would you account for in your 
calculations?
questions.explanation:
500-600 ml of transient loss/insensible loss per day would have to be accounted for in the 
calculation. Although water is lost through sweating especially in hot climates or during physical exertion, we 
tend to lose water at rest as well. Physiologically, water evaporates from the skin and lungs at a 
rate of about 600 to 700 ml/day. This is known as insensible water loss.

questions.question: Question 28: I-125 labelled albumin is used for measurement of:
questions.explanation:
I-125 labelled albumin is the most commonly used substance for the measurement of plasma 
volume. 92 
Sold by @itachibot Physiology of Nerve
